metadata.title: Simultaneously improving the strength and ductility of extruded bimodal size SiCp/AZ61 composites_ Synergistic effect of micron/nano SiCp and submicron Mg17Al12 precipitates

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Science & Engineering A
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/msea
Simultaneously improving the strength and ductility of extruded bimodal size SiCp/AZ61 composites: Synergistic effect of micron/nano SiCp and submicron Mg17Al12 precipitates
Xiaofeng Niua,b, Gang Lia,⁎, Zengyao Zhanga, Pengwen Zhoua, Hongxia Wanga,b,⁎, Shaoxiong Zhanga, Weili Chenga,b
a Shanxi key Laboratory of Advanced Magnesium-Based Materials, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China b School of Materials Science and Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: SiCp/AZ61 composite Extrusion Microstructure Dynamic precipitation Strengthening mechanism
A B S T R A C T
AZ61 matrix reinforced by micro- and nano-scaled SiC particles fabricated via semisolid stirring assisted ultrasonic vibration was subjected to extruded at different speeds (0.1, 0.5 and 2.5 mm/s) with a constant temperature of 280℃. The effect of extrusion speed on the microstructure and tensile properties of the extruded composite was investigated. Grain size, precipitates fraction and texture were found to be greatly affected by the extrusion speed, resulting in tensile properties showing superior strength and ductility as the extrusion speed being of 0.1 mm/s. The improved strength and ductility were ascribed to the synergistic effect of micron/nano SiCp and submicron Mg17Al12 precipitates. The strengthening mechanism of extruded composites was also discussed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Particle-reinforced magnesium matrix composites have aroused extensive attention due to their high specific strength and stiffness, excellent creep resistance and good wear resistance [1]. The common used reinforcing phases suitable for magnesium matrix composites are various, such as: Al2O3 [2,3], Y2O3 [4], SiC [5,6] etc.. Among them, SiCp is widely used because of its low cost and high hardness. Moreover, the strengthening effect of composite is greatly determined by the size of particles in the matrix. On the one hand, micron particles can effectively improve the tensile yield strength of composites, but at the expense of their ductility, the strengthening mechanism is mainly contributed by the grain boundary strengthening and load transfer [7,8]. On the other hand, the nano and submicron sized particles are mainly induced load-transfer effect, thermal mismatch and Orowan strengthening, which can simultaneously improve the strength and ductility of composites [9,10]. In addition, previous report validated that the higher specific surface area induce a higher surface energy of reinforced particles, which lead to a higher density of dislocation around the particles. The interface between SiCp and matrix can act as vacancy sinks which provide efficient diffusion paths of Al element. Thus, the nucleation sites of DRXed grain and Mg17Al12 precipitates are inevitably influenced by the reinforced particles [11,12].
Recently, Deng et al. [5] have successfully prepared a bimodal size (micron + submicron) particles reinforced magnesium matrix composite by stirring casting. The tensile yield strength of the obtained composite is better than that of the single size particle reinforced one, but the elongation has not been significantly improved. In addition, Nie et al. [13] have successfully prepared SiCp/AZ91 nanocomposites with 1% volume fraction of nano-SiCp by ultrasonic vibration method. Compared with the mechanical properties of AZ91 alloy, the strength and elongation of the composites are improved simultaneously. Furthermore, Shen et al. [14] have successfully added micron and nano SiCp (micro/nano volume ratio = 9:1) to the matrix of AZ31, and the performance is much higher than that of single size particle (micron or nano) reinforced magnesium matrix composite. After hot extrusion, the yield strength and tensile strength of the composites are 323MPa and 402MPa, respectively, and the elongation is 8.3%. Based on the above mentioned consideriations, it can be expected that the strength and ductility of composites can be enhanced by inducing multi-scaled reinforcement phases.
Besides, a large number of submicron or nano-size secondary phases are dynamically precipitated along grain boundaries in extruded composites. Sun et al. [15] reported that the fraction of Mg17Al12 precipitated phase increases and its size decrease as the decreasing extrusion speed, which resulted in the improved strength of SiCp/AZ91
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.msea.2018.11.023 Received 10 June 2018; Received in revised form 4 October 2018; Accepted 3 November 2018
⁎ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: leekang2017alpha@qq.com (G. Li), wanghxia1217@163.com (H. Wang).
Materials Science & Engineering A 743 (2019) 207–216
Available online 05 November 2018 0921-5093/ © 2018 Published by Elsevier B.V.
T
composite by precipitation strengthening. Therefore, it can be concluded that the influence of precipitation on the microstructure and mechanical properties of the composites is not negligible. However, it is a pity that little work has been done to study the influence of the synergistic effect of bimodal size SiCp and endogenous Mg17Al12 precipitated phase on the microstructure and mechanical properties of composites.
In the present work, AZ61 matrix reinforced by micro- and nanoscaled SiC particles fabricated via semisolid stirring assisted by ultrasonic vibration was subjected to extrusion at different speeds (0.1, 0.5 and 2.5 mm/s) with a constant temperature of 280℃. The effect of extrusion speed on the microstructure and tensile properties of the extruded composites was investigated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Commercial pure Mg, Al and Zn (99.9 wt%) ingots were used as raw materials, the selected reinforcement is micro/nano SiCp with average
size about 5 µm and 60 nm, and volume fractions is 6% and 1%, respectively. The material was denoted as “M-6+N-1” composite. For comparison, AZ61 alloy is prepared by the same process.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of composites
sections.text:
The material used in this study was a SiCp/AZ61 magnesium matrix composite fabricated by ultrasonic assisted semi-solid stirring casting method. Firstly, alloy ingot with nominal composition of AZ61 (wt%) was melted at 780℃ under the protection of a mixed SF6 (1 vol%) and CO2 (99 vol%) atmosphere in an electric resistance furnace. Then, the melt is cooled to 620℃ which made the matrix alloy in the semi-solid condition. At this point, SiCp, which is preheated to 550℃ for eliminating the moisture, organics and absorbed gases adhering to SiCp, is added to a semi-solid matrix alloy and stirred. After stirring for a certain period of time, the mixed slurry of alloy and SiCp is rapidly heated up to 720℃ and maintained 5min. Then the preheated ultrasonic probe was immersed approximately 20mm into melt. The melt is ultrasonicated at 1600 w for 20min. After ultrasonic stirring, the melt is heated again to 780 °C for 10min. Finally, the melt is poured into a
mould preheated to 300 °C.

sections.heading: 2.3. Hot extrusion of composites
sections.text: Prior to hot extrusion, the ingots of AZ61 and the composites were subjected to solution treatment at 420℃ for 24 h. Then cast billets were cut into samples with the size of Φ 40mm ×h 55mm. The billets were extruded at 280℃ with an extrusion ratio of 16:1. The extrusion speed was set as 0.1, 0.5 and 2.5 mm/s, respectively. Under the same extrusion temperature and extrusion ratio, AZ61 alloy was extruded at the extrusion speed of 0.1mm/s, which can be used as a comparison.

sections.heading: 2.4. Microstructure characterization and tensile test
sections.text:
The microstructures of the specimens were examined by a Leica 2700M optical microscope (OM, Lecia Microsystem GmbH, Wetzlar, Germany), a Mira 3XMU scanning electron microscope (SEM, TESCAN Ltd., Brno-Kohoutovice, Czech Republic) equipped with an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), and a JEM-2100F transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). (0002) and (101̅0) pole figures of the extruded samples were performed with a Y-2000×-ray diffractometer (XRD, Cu-Ka, Dandong Ray Instrument Co., Ltd., Dandong, China). The grain size distribution, average size and volume
fraction of Mg17Al12 phases in SiCp/AZ61 composite was calculated from the optical images by the Image-Pro Plus software. Specimens for TEM were prepared by grinding-polishing the sample to produce a foil with a thickness of 50 µm followed by punching 3mm diameter disks. The disks were ion beam thinned. Repeated tensile test specimen was cut parallel to the extrusion direction with standard dog-bone shape. Three tensile specimens for each sample were performed at room temperature using a DNS100 machine with a speed of 0.1mm/min (SFMIT Ltd. Changzhou, China).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 1 show the optical microstructure and grain size distribution maps of the as-solutioned and as-cast M-6+N-1 composites. As depicted in Fig. 1(a) and (b), coarse grains can be observed in the assolutioned AZ61 alloy, and average grain size is about 84 µm. Fig. 1(c) and (d) show that there are black particles and floc distributing along the grain boundaries, forming typical necklace-like distribution in assolutioned M-6+N-1 composites, and the average grain size of the composites is 30.16 µm. Based on EDS surface scan data, the black particles and floc can be identified as micro SiCp and nano SiCp
clusters. It should be noted that Mg17Al12 phases could also be observed in the as-cast M-6+N-1 composites (see Fig. 1(e) and (f)). Comparing AZ61 alloy and M-6+N-1 composites, it is the addition of SiCp that leads to a finer microstructure in M-6+N-1 composites, which has been already reported [16].
Fig. 2 shows microstructures and grain size distribution maps of asextruded AZ61 and M-6+N-1 composites. After extrusion, the grain size of both AZ61 and the composite was greatly refined compared to that of as-homogenized AZ61. Besides that, a large number of non dynamic recrystallization regions could be observed in extrude AZ61 alloy. However, as-extruded M-6+N-1 composites with the same extrusion speed exhibit complete dynamic recrystallization and relatively small grain size (1.97 µm). As for as-extruded M-6+N-1 composites, after extrusion, the necklace-like distribution of SiCp in the M-6+N-1 composite was broken and elongated along the extrusion direction, as shown in the yellow dashed box in Fig. 2(e) (h) and (k). This phenomenon has been widely reported in many literatures [17,18]. Compared with the as-solutioned M-6+N-1composites, the grains of the extruded M-6+N-1 composites are refined drastically, and the average grain size increases as the extrusion speed increased. According to the literature of Park et al. [19], the average strain rate of composites during hot extrusion can be expressed as follows:
= − ε D V lnER D D ̅ ̇ 6 B R
B E
2
3 3 (4-1)
where VR is the ram speed and DB and DE are the diameters of billet and extruded rod, respectively. The strain rate is proportional to the extrusion speed, namely, the higher extrusion speed leads to the increase of the strain rate, thereby more deformation heat is generated, which provides more energy for recrystallization grain growth. Therefore, the finest grains were obtained at extrusion speed of 0.1 mm/s.
Fig. 3 shows SEM images of AZ61 and the M-6+N-1 composites extruded at different speeds with the temperature of 280℃. As shown in Fig. 3(a), (b) and (c), as-extruded AZ61 could obtain fine dynamic recrystallized grains. And, there are fine particles precipitating at grain boundaries, which can be identified as Mg17Al12 phase through EDS data. In the case of extruded composites, the distribution, morphology and size of particles were greatly depended on the extrusion speeds.
First, the morphology of micro SiCp was not changed significantly, but some cracks can be observed. And the distribution of micro/nano SiCp in the composite is significantly improved and affected by the extrusion speed after hot extrusion. The particle-free zone and the particle-poor zone could be observed at the extrusion speed of 0.1 mm/s and 0.5mm/s, as shown by the red dotted box in Fig. 3(d) and (g). As the extrusion speed rises to 2.5mm/s, homogeneous SiCp distribution was obtained, as shown in Fig. 3(j). As mentioned above, the extrusion temperature rises with the increase of the extrusion speed, which indicates that more deformation heat is generated. The increased deformation heat can increase the fluidity of AZ61 matrix and promote the coordination of the deformation between the SiCp and the matrix, consequently, the uniform distribution of SiCp is obtained at 2.5 mm/s. Besides, the formation of nano SiCp band was observed, as shown in the yellow dotted box in Fig. 3(e), (h) and (k). The reason is that the nano SiCp clusters form the enrichment zone along the extrusion direction after extrusion. As the increase of extrusion speed, the number of nano
SiCp bands decreased, and the SiCp agglomeration in nano SiCp and near micro SiCp were improved. This is attributed to the fact that more deformation heat is generated at higher extrusion speeds, making the flow velocity of the matrix much faster than that of nano SiCp, so that the matrix can easily flow into the nano SiCp bands [19].
In addition, the dynamic precipitation of the Mg17Al12 phase is meaningfully affected by the extrusion speed during extrusion. It can be seen from Fig. 3(f), (i) and (l) that profuse Mg17Al12 phases could be found along the grain boundaries of the DRXed grains. The diameter and volume fraction of Mg17Al12 precipitates at different extrusion conditions are presented in Table 1. As the extrusion speed was decreased from 2.5 mm/s to 0.1mm/s, the volume fraction of Mg17Al12 precipitated phase increased from 5.2% to 11.3%, and its average diameter decreased from 0.32 µm to 0.23 µm. This behavior is consistent with the Sun et al. observations based on SiCp/AZ91 composite [13]. The higher volume fraction of Mg17Al12 precipitates is obtained at 0.1 mm/s may be related to the sufficient nucleation time at slower extrusion speeds [13,20]. Furthermore, the slower extrusion would lead to the weakening of the fluidity of the matrix. Thus, the matrix's fragmentation effect on the Mg17Al12 precipitated phase is enhanced [21].
Fig. 4 depicts the TEM images and corresponding EDS results of the M-6+N-1 composites extruded at speed of 0.1mm/s. The precipitate phase in Fig. 4(b) could be identified as Mg17Al12 phase based on EDS results. The results from Fig. 4(c) show that the precipitated phase is rich in Mg and Al elements, with only a little of Zn elements, and further confirmed that the precipitated phase is Mg17Al12 phase. From the EDS mapping of the Si element, it can be observed that the nano SiCp is uniformly distributed in the matrix although some nano SiCp clusters still exist. similar phenomenon was reported in many previous reports [17,22].
Fig. 5 shows the (0002) pole figure of the M-6+N-1 composites extruded at different speeds. All as-extruded M-6+N-1 composites exhibited a texture with (0002) base plane parallel to extrusion direction, which is a typical texture of the as-extruded alloys [23]. The basal plane texture of present composites extruded at 0.1 mm/s is weaker than that of the counterpart one at 2.5 mm/s, which indicates that the intensity of basal plane texture tend to be increased with the increase of extrusion speed. This is contrary to previous reports [24]. Numerous studies have shown that [22,25] second phase could influence the intensity of deformation texture. Mg17Al12 precipitated phases provided more randomly oriented nuclei during extrusion, compared with the original structure, the newly formed grain orientation is more random, leading to the weakening of the base plane texture of the composite. Consequently, the decreasing amount of Mg17Al12 phases leads to the strengthening basal plane texture with increasing extrusion speed.
The TEM images of the M-6+N-1 composites extruded at 0.1 mm/s are shown in Fig. 6. It can be seen from Fig. 6(a) that nano SiCp dispersed uniformly in the vicinity of micron SiCp. Besides, fine Mg17Al12 precipitates are also observed near the micron SiCp (see Fig. 6(b)). It can be deduced that the existence of micron SiCp is favorable to the precipitation of Mg17Al12 phase. This is attributed to the fact that particle deformation zones (PDZs) with high dislocation densities and larger orientation angles are easily formed near the micro-SiCp during the deformation [26,27]. High dislocation density effectively promotes the diffusion of Al elements, allowing the enrichment of Al elements near the micron SiCp. In addition, the SiCp/Mg interface provides an effective diffusion path for Al elements by reason of the presence of va3cancies at the SiCp/Mg interface [28]. These factors make it easy for the Al element near the micro SiCp to reach the supersaturated state and then precipitate as the Mg17Al12 phase. Fig. 6(c) is selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of in the yellow dashed box of Fig. 6(b), which can be confirmed as a face centered cubic nano SiCp. In Fig. 6(d), abundant dislocations can be observed near micron SiCp. This can be explained from the following two aspects: Firstly, a large number of dislocations accumulate near the particles due to the difference of coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) between AZ61 matrix and
particles, which increases the dislocation density significantly [3,29]. Then, distorted regions with high density of dislocations are easily formed near the micro SiCp owing to the deformation mismatch between the hard-deformed SiCp and the soft matrix during deformation, is called PDZ [30]. Fig. 6(e) is the diffraction spot of precipitated phase in Fig. 6(b), further validating that the precipitated phase is Mg17Al12 phase. As can be seen from Fig. 6(f), a lot of dislocations are stacked around the Mg17Al12 phase and nano SiCp, while the grain boundary also effectively hinders the movement of dislocations, leading to dislocation accretion. It is shown that the Mg17Al12 phase and the nanoSiCp located at the grain boundary can effectively pin grain boundaries and hinder the dislocation movement [31,32], which promotes the dynamic recrystallization nucleation of the matrix and leads to grain
refinement. According to the above microstructural observation and analysis, the schematic illustration of matrix microstructure influenced by bimodal sized SiCp during extrusion was established, as shown in Fig. 7. Firstly, the micron SiCp is easy to form around the micron particles PDZ due to the extremely uncoordinated deformation between the particles and the matrix during extrusion process, the region has a higher dislocation density and distortion degree, which is conducive to recrystallization nucleation of matrix grains. Secondly, the nano SiCp in the vicinity of micron SiCp also impede the dislocation movement, causing the dislocation to be stacked in the area near the micron particles, further improving the dislocation density around the micron particles, and the nano SiCp will play the role of pinning the grain
boundary, limiting the further growth of the recrystallized grains. Finally, it is easy to form thermal mismatch dislocations around the micron SiCp as a result of the large difference in the CTE between the SiCp and the AZ61 matrix. In addition, it can be seen from Fig. 7(b) that the movement of partial dislocations is also hindered by the original grain boundary, and dislocation pile-up at grain boundaries. During the deformation process, PDZ around the micro SiCp and grain boundaries with higher dislocation density preferentially recrystallize nucleation, and the presence of nano SiCp also inhibits the growth of recrystallized grains, as shown in Fig. 7(c). Therefore, the grain in the area near the bimodal size particles is smaller than the one far away from the region, as shown in Fig. 7(d).
Fig. 8(a) shows the mechanical properties of AZ61 and M-6+N-1 composites. Due to addition of micro/nano SiCp, the strength of as-cast and as-extruded M-6+N-1 composites can be enhanced obviously but elongation decreased, which has been reported in the previous paper [15]. After further analysis of as-extruded M-6+N-1 composites with different extrusion speed, the strength and elongation of the as-
extruded M-6+N-1 composites are improved simultaneously compared with the as-cast M-6+N-1 composite. As shown in Fig. 8(a) and (b), the yield strength (YS) and tensile strength (UTS) of the as-extruded composites decreased as the extrusion speed increased, its elongation (EL) increased firstly and then decreased as increasing extrusion speed. The optimal mechanical properties were obtained when M-6+N-1 composite was extruded at 0.1 mm/s, where the YS= 295MPa, the UTS=360MPa and the EL=9.5%. the enhancement of strength is mainly ascribed to grain refinement, Orowan strengthening, the higher mismatch strengthening and load bearing caused by micron/nano SiCp and submicron Mg17Al12 Precipitates.
The contribution of grain refinement to YS can be calculated by the Hall-Petch formula [33]:
= + −σ kdσy 0 1 2 (1)
where σy is the YS, σ0 is the material constants, d is the matrix grain diameter, k is the Hall-Petch slopes taking value of 0.13MPam1/2. Compared with as-cast M-6+N-1 composite, the increase of YS caused
by grain refinement in as-extruded M-6+N-1 composites can be estimated as follows:
⎜ ⎟∆ = ⎛ ⎝ − ⎞ ⎠ − − − k d dσ ec ccHall Petch 1 2 1 2
(2)
where dec and dcc are the average grain size of as-extruded M-6+N-1 composites and as-cast M-6+N-1 composite, respectively. Therefore, for M-6+N-1 composite extruded at speeds of 0.1mm/s, 0.5 mm/s, 2.5 mm/s, it can be calculated that the contribution of yield strength due to grain refinement is 92.14MPa, 60.24MPa, 49.81MPa, respectively.
Table 1 shows that the diameters of the Mg17Al12 precipitated phases in composites extruded at speeds of 0.1mm/s, 0.5 mm/s, 2.5 mm/s are 0.23 µm, 0.28 µm, and 0.32 µm, respectively, which is much less than 1 µm. Besides, a lot of dislocations are stacked around the Mg17Al12 phase and nano SiCp by TEM observed (see Fig. 6(f)). Therefore, the Orowan strengthening effect caused by submicron
Mg17Al12 precipitates and dispersed nano SiCp in the matrix cannot be neglected. When dislocation line encounters submicron or nanoparticle, the dislocation line bypasses the enhanced particle or bends along the enhanced particle to form a dislocation loop [34]. The contribution of Orowan strengthening to the YS of the composite can be calculated by the following equation [35]:
∆ = −

where λp is inter-particle spacing described by Eq. (4) [5].

where d is the average diameter of particles, f is volume fraction of particles. The required parameter values for the calculation are given in Table 2. Combined Eqs. (3) and (4), it can be calculated that the contribution of Orowan strengthening caused by submicron Mg17Al12 precipitates to the yield strength in the composite extruded at speeds of
0.1 mm/s, 0.5 mm/s, 2.5 mm/s are 20.7 MPa, 13.9 MPa, 8.8MPa, respectively. In this regard, the contribution of Orowan strengthening from n-SiCP precipitates is 11.91MPa.
The difference in the thermal expansion coefficient (CTE) between the AZ61 matrix and the SiCp results in geometrically necessary dislocations and induces residual thermal stresses, which play a reinforcing role, called thermal mismatch strengthening. In fact, the contribution of thermal mismatch strengthening to YS by Mg17Al12 phase is negligible due to a little distinction CTE between matrix and the Mg17Al12 phase [36]. The increment of YS caused by thermal mismatch strengthening can be calculated by the following equation [3,5,37]:
∆ = ∆ ∆
− σ βG b V α T V bd 3 12 (1 )CTE m p
p p (5)
where β is strengthening coefficient, Δα is the difference between CTE of matrix and SiCp, ΔT is the difference between extrusion temperature and room temperature. b is the Bourne's vector, and dp and Vp are the average size and volume fraction of the enhanced particles, respectively. Thus, according to Eq. (5), it can be calculated that the contribution of thermal mismatch strengthening to the yield strength in the composite extruded at different speeds is 19.8 MPa.
The load transfer from the soft matrix to the hard reinforcements during tensile, especially when there is a good interfacial integrity between the two phases, is called the load bearing effect, Δload. The yield strength increment caused by load transfer can be calculated by formula (6) [3,38].
∆ =σ V σ0.5load mp (6)
where Vp represents the volume fraction of the reinforcing phase, and σm is the yield stress of the matrix. In fact, according to Eq. (6), it can be calculated that the contribution of load bearing effect to the yield strength caused by the SiCP is 7.46MPa.
To summarize, as shown in Table 3, the optimal mechanical properties were obtained when M-6+N-1 composite was extruded at 0.1 mm/s. The dominant strengthening mechanism is grain boundary strengthening caused by grain refinement and Orowan strengthening caused by profuse submicron precipitates.
Fig. 9 shows the fractograph of the M-6+N-1 composites extruded at different extrusion speed. As shown in Fig. 9(a) (b) and (c), obvious SiCp-Mg interfacial debonding is observed (see the yellow box). As the extrusion speed increases, the phenomenon of interfacial debonding

decreases, indicating that the SiCp-Mg interfacial bond is relatively strong at higher extrusion speed. This is ascribed to the fact that more deformation heat is generated at higher extrusion speeds, increasing the SiCp-matrix interfacial bonding strength by the improvement of matrix fluidity. Plenty of dimples can be found at 0.1mm/s, this is conducive to the improvement of plasticity. Moreover, the aforementioned texture results shown that more random texture exist in the composites extruded at 0.1 mm/s, which can produce more dislocation slip and thus increase the EL of the materials [39]. Note that, microcracks can be observed from Fig. 9(d), (e) and (f), the initiation of microcracks is mainly due to the tensile stress exceeding the bonding strength of between SiCp and the matrix. As the microcracks extend further along the SiCp/Mg interface to the whole matrix and the composite will fracture. Therefore, interface debonding can be considered as the main fracture mechanism of extruded M-6+N-1 composites.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: (1) As extrusion speeds increased, the average grain size and texture intensity of composite increased, while the fraction of precipitates including added SiCp and dynamic precipitated Mg17Al12 decreased. (2) The yield strength (YS) and tensile strength (UTS) of the composites decreased as the extrusion speed increase, while, elongation (EL) increased firstly and then decreased as increments of extrusion speed. The superior mechanical properties were obtained when M6+N-1 composite was extruded at 0.1mm/s with the temperature of 280℃, exhibiting the YS= 295MPa, the UTS=360MPa and the EL=9.5%. (3) The dominant strengthening mechanism was grain boundary strengthening caused by grain refinement and Orowan strengthening caused by profuse submicron precipitates. The enhanced ductility was related to weaken basalt texture and remarkable grain refinement.

metadata.abstractText: AZ61 matrix reinforced by microand nano-scaled SiC particles fabricated via semisolid stirring assisted ultrasonic vibration was subjected to extruded at different speeds (0.1, 0.5 and 2.5 mm/s) with a constant temperature of 280°C. The effect of extrusion speed on the microstructure and tensile properties of the extruded composite was investigated. Grain size, precipitates fraction and texture were found to be greatly affected by the extrusion speed, resulting in tensile properties showing superior strength and ductility as the extrusion speed being of 0.1 mm/s. The improved strength and ductility were ascribed to the synergistic effect of micron/nano SiCp and submicron Mg17Al12 precipitates. The strengthening mechanism of extruded composites was also discussed.
